To play Euchre, you need four players in two teams of two, a standard, 52-card deck of, playing cards, and something you can use to keep score (such as this app). 
 
Team members are seated across from one another. 
 
Before you begin, remove all cards less than 9 from the deck (i.e. 2 through 8). You will not use those cards at all.

Chose the first dealer however you like. That player shuffles the deck and deals it out evenly among all players in alternating groups of two and three cards. Each player should have five cards in his or her hand after dealing.\n
For example, if Player 1 is the dealer, he or she deals two cards to Player 2, three to Player 3, two to Player 4, three to him- or herself, then three to Player 2, and so on.\n

After dealing, there will be four cards remaining. Turn the top card of this pile over and place the pile in the middle. 
 
Each player, starting with the player to the dealer's left, now has the opportunity to call the round's trump suit based on the face-up card in the center. If he or she wishes to do so, the dealer must take the face-up card and replace one card in his or her hand with it (i.e. by placing a different card from his or her hand face-down on the pile).

For example, if the face-up card is the A♥ and Player 3 calls the trump suit, then the dealer takes the A♥ and adds it into his or her hand. Then, he or she must remove a different card from his or her hand, for example, the 9♠, and place it face-down on the pile. ♥ is now the trump suit for that round.\n

If the first player (to the left of the dealer) does not wish to call the trump suit, he or she may pass, and the decision now goes to the player to his or her left. 
 
This continues until either the dealer has taken the face-up card or until all four players have passed. If the dealer takes the face-up card, that card's suit is now the trump suit for the round. If not, starting with the player to the dealer's left, each player has the opportunity to call the round's trump suit by naming a suit.
Tip: Calling the trump suit, whether by making the dealer take the face-up card or by naming the suit, should be based off of the cards in your hand.\n

The player to dealer\'s left plays first. He or she places a card from his or her hand face-up in the middle. Continuing to the left, each player plays a card from his or her hand in the same manner. However, each player must play a card in the same suit as the leading card (the first card played) if possible. If a player does not have a card in the leading suit, then he or she may play any card.\n
To play Nerts, you need any number of players, a standard, 52-card deck of playing cards for each player, and something you can use to keep score (such as this app).\n
Be sure that each deck has a different back design. Thereason for this will be explained later.\n

Each player shuffles his or her deck and places the top 13 cards face-up in a pile. This is that player's Nerts pile. Then, he or she places four cards face-up in a row next to the Nerts pile. 
 
The four cards in a row can be played onto following the rules of Solitaire:

A player may stack a card on top of another card if the card being played is of the opposite color and has a value one lower than the card below it. 
 
For example, if the lowest card in the stack is the Q♥, you may stack either the J♠ or the J♣ on it. 
 
A player may move one stack onto another, provided this rule is not broken. Players may not play a card underneath another card.
Aces (A) are played in the middle of all players. Again, these cards are played onto following the rules of Solitaire, with a twist: Any player may play onto the cards in the middle.\n

A player may stack a card on top of another card if the card being played is of the same suit as and has a value exactly one greater than the card below it. 
 
For example, if an A♠ is in the middle, any player may play a 2♠ on it. Any player may then play a 3♠ on the stack and so on. 
 
Tip: It is helpful to flip over a pile when playing the King (K) of that pile, so that players can more easily know that the pile has been completed.

If multiple players attempt to play the same card onto a pile, the card that reaches the pile first stays, while the other cards must be taken back. 
 
Any cards that are not in the starting 17 are kept in a face-down deck. Players use these cards by drawing three at a time and playing the cards in order from top to bottom, if possible.
For example, if a player draws 6♣, K♥, and 9♠, in that order, he or she must play the 9♠ before the K♥ and the K♥ before the 6♣.\n

If a player cannot play the top card of the cards he or she has drawn, then he or she may draw three more cards and continue this process. If a player has drawn all the cards in his or her deck, that player takes the drawn cards, flips the pile face-down, and may continue drawing cards. 
 
Players may use the top card of their Nerts pile as normal, with one exception: The top card of the Nerts pile may not be played in the individual Solitaire area (the row of four cards in front of each player) unless there is an open space in the row, in which case the card may be placed in that space. 
 
Play continues in this way until a player plays all 13 cards from his or her Nerts pile and calls out, "Nerts!"
If multiple players call \"Nerts!\" at the about the same time, it is up to the other players to determine whether one player called \"Nerts!\" first or if the players tie.\n
After a player calls \"Nerts!\", players may not play any more cards. Any cards being played as \"Nerts!\" is called must be taken back.\n

The cards in the middle are sorted by player, that is, by the cards\' back designs, and each player counts the number of cards he or she played in the middle. Each player then subtracts from that amount the number of cards remaining in his or her Nerts pile. This number is that player\'s round total.\n
For example, if a player played 16 cards in the middle and had 5 cards remaining in his or her Nerts pile, that player\'s round total would be 11 points.\n
This number is then added onto the player\'s previous score to form that player\'s new total score.\n

Play continues in this way until one or more players reach or exceed a winning point value. This value can be any amount, though 100 points is a good amount. The player with the most points wins the game.
To play Rich Cards, you need four or more players, a standard, 52-card deck of playing cards without the Jokers, and something you can use to keep score (such as this app).\n

Although you can play with any number of players (up to 52, at least), it is not recommended to play with more than seven; it is best to play with four players, since no cards must be removed. If the group is larger than seven, consider splitting into multiple groups.\n
You will need a number of cards evenly divisible by the number of players. This means that you may need to remove some cards from the deck before you begin.\n

4 Players: Use all 52 cards 
5 Players: Use 50 cards 
6 Players: Use 48 cards 
7 Players: Use 49 cards 
And so on.
Do not remove just any cards, as doing so will affect the scoring.\n

Here are some examples of cards that are OK to remove: 
5 Players: 6♣, 6♦ 
6 Players: 5♦, 6♠, 7♣, 6♦ 
7 Players: 5♠, 6♦, 7♣
Should you choose to remove cards other than these, make sure not to remove any ♥ cards (See Scoring). If possible, don\'t remove high- or low-value cards, such as Aces (A), 2s, Jacks (J), etc.\n

Chose the first dealer however you like. That player shuffles the deck and deals it out evenly among all players. 
 
The player to dealer's left plays first. He or she places a card from his or her hand face-up in the middle. This card's suit is the trump suit for the trick. Continuing to the left, each player plays a card from his or her hand in the same manner. However, each player must play a card of the trump suit if possible. If a player does not have a card in the trump suit, then he or she may play any card.
For example, if Player 1 plays the 4♣, then every player must play a ♣ if he or she has a ♣ in his or her hand. If, however, Player 3 has no ♣s, then he or she may instead play a ♦.\n
Once all players have played a card, the player who played the highest-valued card in the trump suit—Aces are high—takes the trick (all the cards played that round).\n

For example, if the cards in the trick are: 
Player 1: 6♥, 
Player 2: 3♥, 
Player 3: J♠, and 
Player 4: 7♥; 
then Player 4 takes the trick. Even though Player 3's J♠ has a higher value, it is not in the leading suit (♥) and is therefore not considered when determining who takes the trick.

The player who took the trick then leads the next one. 
 
Play continues in this way until either all cards have been played or there are no more possible points in the round (See Scoring). After the round is over, the player to the left of the previous round's dealer becomes the dealer for the new round.
There are six rounds in a game, each with its own scoring method. The rounds are scored as follows:\n

Round 1: 10 points for each trick. 
Round 2: 10 points for each ♥ card. 
Round 3: 25 points for each Queen (Q) card. 
Round 4: 100 points for the K♠. 
Round 5: 100 points for the last trick. 
Round 6: Use all previous scoring methods.

Note that in Rounds 2, 3, and 4, it is possible to finish the round before all cards have been played. If there are no more cards left in players\' hands that are worth points, then the round is over.\n
For example, in Round 4, if a player takes the K♠ in the fifth trick, then the round is over, because the K♠ is the only card worth points.\n
At the end of the game, each player\'s scores are added together to produce that player\'s final score. The player with the fewest points wins the game.

Euchre is a plain-trick game. Teams try to win three of the five tricks per round, with the goal of reaching ten points.
Nerts is a highly competitive patience game. Players try to get rid of all the cards in their Nerts piles by playing onto common piles.
Rich Cards is a plain-trick game with a twist: Each of the six rounds has its own scoring method and thus, its own strategy.
